Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research Experience for Undegraduate in Computational Methods in High Performace Computing with Applications to Computer Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The site is supported by the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program.
The award provides support for a three-year REU Site at the College of Staten Island (City University of New York) with technical support from CUNY's High Performance Computing Center, in an area of increasing national importance: Computational Methods in High Performance Computing with Applications in Computer Science. The REU Site recruits eight undergraduate students, for a ten-week summer experience, who undertake challenging problems with their mentors, in different research sub-fields of computer science (e.g., Graph Theory, Network Reliability, Cryptography, Network Security, Wireless Ad-hoc, Sensor Networks, and Complex Systems Modeling and Simulation) that require parallel processing programming techniques to be solved. Selected students develop competency in scientific research, improve oral presentations and writing skills. The program is aimed to help students produce significant research results which are written up in a format acceptable for publication in either a conference or journal.

Students are recruited from colleges and universities that offer limited or no STEM research opportunities, such as historically minority colleges and universities. Emphasis is placed on attracting minority and female students. Research and technical activities are integrated with group activities which include site visits to state-of-the art research facilities in the New York metropolitan area, seminars conducted by faculty, and social activities to enhance the diversity of the group. Seminars in career development, ethical issues in computer science, literature search, technical writing, and graduate school advisement, are integral parts of the program. The program is expected to draw students into research and provide them with the intellectual and motivational tools to engage them in graduate studies and pursue research careers in computer science or related fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The College of Staten Island (CUNY) in collaboration with CUNY's High Performance Computing Center, have run a three-year, ten-week REU Site "Computational Methods in High Performance Computing with Applications to Computer Science" (e.g., Graph Theory, Network Reliability, Cryptography, Network Security, Machine Learning, Complex Systems Modeling and Simulations). Each Summer eight  undergraduate students were first trained on computational methods based upon the implementation of programming models (e.g., MPI, CUDA, etc.) on system architectures that support parallelism. Meanwhile, under the supervision of their mentors, students undertook challenging problems in different fields of computer science requiring parallel/distributed processing techniques to be solved.

Program Goals

1) Participants have developed competency in scientific research, oral presentations and writing skills; 2) In collaboration with their mentors, students  produced significant research results which were written up in a format acceptable for publication in either a conference or journal; 3) Participants have learned how to present as well as disseminate the research results; 4) Students sustained their interests in graduate studies and research careers in computer science or related fields.

Intellectual Merit

The intellectual merit of the REU program is that students had a unique opportunity to learn theoretical and applied concepts in computer science while getting training in parallel processing languages and architectures. The support of CUNY's High Performance Computing Center was essential for the successful completion of the projects. Eight papers were presented by the ex-participants at international conferences, in which one student received the best paper award. One paper was published in SIURO (SIAM Undergraduate Research On-line), and additionally, the participants presented their research at twenty-four local school workshops and/or undergraduate conferences. 

Broader Impact

Students from colleges and universities with no or limited STEM research opportunities were the primary recruitment target, with emphasis placed in the recruitment of minorities and women. The students were drawn into careers in computer science or related fields, and several have pursued or are planning to continue with graduate studies in related areas of research.
